Software Engineering Project - Course Guide

Project: Design and Build a TypeScript ORM Library (Deno/JSR) with Multi-Database Support

Project Description

In this project, you will work as a team to design and implement an Object-Relational Mapping (ORM) library in TypeScript, optimized for the Deno runtime and published via JSR. The ORM should abstract common database operations across multiple relational databases and offer developers a clean, safe, and extensible API. Optionally, it may be extended to support NoSQL datastores or Node.js compatibility.

This project emphasizes both technical depth (patterns, architecture, performance, security) and professional practices (teamwork, iterative workflow, documentation, and open-source release).

Goal

Deliver a robust, modular, and reusable ORM library that enables developers to quickly and safely integrate databases into their applications. The focus should be on:

  • Ease of use (approachable interface, quick setup)
  • Reliability (well-tested, secure)
  • Extensibility (easy to add new drivers, features)
  • Maintainability (clean architecture, strong documentation)

Context

The rise of modern JavaScript runtimes like Deno, combined with the diversity of available databases, has created demand for lightweight, platform-agnostic ORMs. Many existing solutions target Node.js or a single database. This project explores a Deno-first, standards-based ORM that can evolve to support multiple backends and potentially interoperate with Node.js.

Desired Outcome

A stable and well-documented ORM library that:

  • Works out-of-the-box (one-command setup)
  • Supports typical CRUD operations, relations, transactions, and migrations
  • Provides a query builder DSL with method chaining
  • Is published on JSR and open-sourced on GitHub
  • Includes tests, runnable examples, CI/CD pipeline, and architecture documentation

Example DSL (you will define the exact API):

const users = await orm.query('User')
  .where('age', '>', 18)
  .orderBy('createdAt', 'desc')
  .limit(10)
  .execute();

Functional Requirements

Must-Haves

  • Implemented in TypeScript, compatible with Deno, and publishable via JSR

  • Support at least 3 relational databases (e.g., PostgreSQL, MySQL/MariaDB, SQLite) through adapters/drivers

  • Provide:

    • CRUD operations
    • Relations (1-N, N-N, etc.)
    • Transactions and schema migrations
    • Query builder DSL with chaining

  • Local dev setup with Docker Compose for databases

Could-Haves

  • Support for at least one NoSQL database via the same adapter interface
  • CLI tool for schema/migration management
  • Node.js/NPM compatibility layer
  • Plug-in system for custom drivers or behaviors
  • Optimizations: eager vs lazy loading, batching, connection pooling

Non-Functional Requirements

  • Testability: high coverage on core modules (unit + integration)

  • Modularity: clear separation of core, adapters, and drivers (Ports & Adapters recommended)

  • Security: parameterized queries, safe credential handling, protection against SQL injection, mass assignment, etc.

  • Performance: basic benchmarks (CRUD throughput, relation fetches)

  • Documentation:

    • README (Quick start, Features, Troubleshooting)
    • API docs (TSDoc/Typedoc)
    • Architecture notes and decision records
    • Example projects

  • Release & OSS: GitHub repo, MIT/Apache-2.0 license, CI/CD with lint/test/build, changelog, SemVer, tagged releases

Research & Decision Making

You are expected to:

  • Compare ORM patterns (Active Record vs Data Mapper, etc.)
  • Explore migration strategies and query APIs
  • Benchmark adapter performance
  • Record major choices as Architecture Decision Records (ADRs)
  • Study existing ORMs for inspiration (API ergonomics, migrations, driver design)

Project Requirements

  • Team size: 3 students

  • Workflow: Agile/Scrum/Kanban (iterative with code reviews)

  • Repository: GitHub repo with issues/boards

  • Setup: One-command startup (e.g., deno task dev or docker compose up)

  • Environment: .env.example with defaults (no secrets in repo)

  • CI/CD: Linting, testing, building on push

  • Deliverables:

    • Source code + documentation in GitHub
    • Example apps and runnable demos
    • Research report & ADRs
    • Final presentation and reflection

  • Research:

    • Follow the Research guideline (research question, core concepts, comparative analysis, technology evaluation).
    • Run small experiments/benchmarks where relevant and cite evidence.

Assessment Criteria

  1. Research & Analysis – quality of investigation and justification of choices
  2. Functional Working – completeness, stability, usability
  3. Technical Quality – architecture, testability, performance, security
  4. Documentation – clarity, completeness, accessibility
  5. Teamwork & Process – iteration, collaboration, use of tools
  6. Presentation & Reflection – ability to explain and defend your solution

Definition of Done

The project is done when:

  • Research completed and documented:
    • Research question, core concepts, and comparative analysis are written up
    • Experiments/benchmarks included where relevant
  • The ORM meets all must-have requirements
  • At least 3 RDBMS adapters are working
  • All tests pass in CI/CD with high coverage
  • Documentation is complete
  • The library is published via JSR and open-sourced
  • At least one example project demonstrates usage
  • Team delivers final presentation and reflection
